author: tbilisi.andrew
title: Continuing in Georgia (country)
description: Грузия использует технологию blockchain, чтобы сделать каждую часть общественной жизни лучше, проблема в том, что у них нет средств для ее внедрения.

f6_assessments.q0:
The identified problem shouldn't be the lack of funds necessary to implement  a project (the meaning of this campaign is to fund viable proposals) but rather and obstacle on the path to progress (a problem could be the lack of evidence of national plastic recyclers and the output of their activities).

Unfortunately it is unclear for an outsider why is the best to fund a pilot project that is on-chain (what are the constrains of a classical not-on-chain project) as is stated in the provided solution.

If the proposer will go one step at a time and chose a viable direction for this project, the proposal may fit in the challenge brief, but it requires reworking to make things more clear. If the proposer wants to create materials for presentation then the proposal fits better in another challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
It is unclear what is the relevant experience of the proposer and/or the team members (if there are any) that will implement this proposal, the only reference mentioned being about a good connection with the Georgia Government representatives which is necessary but not enough for a successful implementation.

The budget is outlined but is not broken down into identifiable items (human resources - programmers, administrative staff etc. - devices, stationary etc.).

The proposal provides a conductible plan for implementation that shows what is being done and how (whitepaper attached).

The proposal doesn't explain technical aspects like architecture, language and technologies if they are crucial for implementation.

The proposer has considered some of the challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation but, as long as Georgia is knocking on EU's doors, they should be aware of an EU Regulation (it might be a pre-admission requirement to comply with) that set a mechanism to pay a fee to the users who return to the seller the (plastic) recipients they have bought. (how the token distribution system will survive to this threat?)
f6_assessments.q2:
There are no KPIs/metrics defined to measure the success of the implementation of this project.

The proposal reads like a concept more than an executable proposal. It needs more editing so that it can be assessed properly given its direction. Perhaps reworking it and submitting it at the later stages will work.
f6_assessments.reply: The issue confronting adopitbility of larger scale projects is - from our experience - one of larger buy in.  In order to get any project like this off the ground, one first has to start.  We included 3 projects as ALL are possible within the country of Georgia, but really only 2 of the 3 would likely move forward.  We are unable to predict which 2 of the projects would happen but it is more likely that there would be some success within the broader scope.  Taking the first steps on behalf of Cardano and Catalyst, greatly improve the chances of wider scale buy in - but it also imbeds the Cardano blockchain as part of the solution.  As it is difficult to predict which project would succeed and how the project would 'look', it is not easy to establish the KPI's.  Our team does, however, have the access within the country to make projects like this happen.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal is a solution that falls within the scope of the challenge.

The proposal adds value to the Cardano ecosystem, in the form of more users of the Cardano ecosystem.

The goals of the project are defined and align with the challenge but the goals are a selection of possible options. There are no key metrics defining success.

How scalability will be achieved is not addressed in the proposal.

To improve the proposal: choose the projects to be implemented instead of having possible options or submit separate proposals for each project, provide key metrics for success, address scalability in the proposal.
f6_assessments.q1:
The proposer provides evidence of relevant skills and experience needed to implement the proposal.
The proposer does not identify the type and number of team members required to implement the proposal.
The budget is not clearly broken down into identifiable items. 
The budget seems light to achieve the set goals of two pilot projects over a 6-12 month period however that may be due to local labour rates which are not defined in the proposal.
The proposal has a timetable to complete the work.
The proposal does not explain technical aspects of the implementation.
The proposal does not include challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation.
To improve the proposal: identify the team and skill sets required to implement the proposal, breakdown the budget into specific items especially salaries, explain technical aspects of proposal, include a challenges and risks section
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal does include a roadmap with milestones and a time horizon for achievement. 
The proposal does not provide metrics/KPIs that define the success of the proposal. 
The proposal provides a clear understandable description of the targeted problem.
The proposal provides several understandable solutions that addresses the problem but only seeks to solve 2 of the 3 solutions.
To improve the proposal: provide metrics/KPIs that measure progress, choose the projects to be implemented instead of having possible options or submit separate proposals for each project

f6_assessments.q0: I think the projects are really promising and would be highly impactful, especially given the possibility of its implementation and testing in the public space. However, it's hard to assess the impact generated within the scope of Fund 7 since the proposal has not yet established the validity for its feasibility and accountability whist successfully receiving the funding.
f6_assessments.q1:
To establish its validity, I think the proposer can put more effort and add more depth into his proposal for the next round of funding. To make it simple, he can choose one specific project and write his implementation plan in details, rather than leaving the decision to choose 2 or 3 projects later. Or else, he should have a good reason for that. 

For the implementation plan, it'd be better for voters to decide if he can write down: (1) his and his team's experience, (2) evidence of his past work, especially on his unique position to push the project forward (3) action plan with clear timeline, milestones and KPIs, (4) team roles, (5) budget breakdown, (6) anticipated challenges and counter plan.
f6_assessments.q2: Since no project has been chosen and thus no implementation plan accompanied, it would be impossible to audit the progress of this proposal.
f6_assessments.reply: Because the nature of this proposal  is more open, all expenses would be placed with invoices, notes and 3rd party journalism articles (all imbedded within metadata of Cardano).  We feel that this project is entirely auditable and can be judged fairly as a success or failure based on the results.

solution: Лучше всего полностью профинансировать пилотные проекты, которые нацелены на демонстрацию, а затем осуществить настоящие изменения в масштабах страны. Давайте сделаем два пилотных проекта.
experience: Я руководил программой отслеживания/трекинга Baia's Wine/Cardano. Я консультирую правительство Грузии по техническим вопросам и могу разместить дополнительные проекты в правительстве.
